title: Anadarko Says Occidental Now 'Superior' Offer to Chevron
summary: The development puts Occidental ahead in the battle to buy Anadarko and its coveted Permian Basin assets. Anadarko Petroleum Corp. said Monday that a $38 billion bid by Occidental Petroleum Corp. was superior to an offer it accepted from Chevron Corp. , raising the stakes in the battle for the company.

title: U.S. Measles Cases Continue to Climb
summary: New York state legislators square off on bid to end exemption from vaccinations based on 'genuine and sincere religious beliefs'. As measles cases rose last week to a new high of 764 cases this year in 23 states, a battle is heating up in New York state over a proposal to tighten vaccination requirements for those attending schools.

title: Health Startup uBiome Suspends Two Lab Tests
summary: FBI searched company's offices last month amid billing probe; some insurers had stopped payments. UBiome Inc. said it would suspend performing two lab tests that it had been billing to insurers, the latest sign of trouble at the startup that had its offices searched by the Federal Bureau of Investigation late last month.

title: Trump's China Brinksmanship
summary: The incentives for a deal are overwhelming on both sides.. President Trump roiled financial markets Monday with his threats to impose a new round of tariffs on China as trade talks hit an impasse. We're about to find out if tariff brinksmanship pays off in a productive deal or ends in mutual escalation that will hurt both countries.

title: An NAACP Revolt on Charters
summary: Three local chapters in California oppose a union-led moratorium.. Good news from the front lines of school reform: Three local chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored people in California are bucking teachers unions and their own national organization to oppose a moratorium on charter schools. The LA School Report saysNAACP chapters in San Diego, San Bernardino and Riverside have filed resolutions opposing a moratorium that the national NAACP has pushed under pressure from teachers unions that are a source of its funding.

title: A Warning to Soleimani
summary: The U.S. sends a signal to the commander of Iran's Quds Force.. The White House said Sunday it will deploy an aircraft carrier strike group and a bomber task force to the Persian Gulf. This isn't a provocation but a deterrence message for Iran, its Middle Eastern proxies, and especially Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani.

title: Winning a Tony Brings Broadway Glory, and Sometimes a Bonus
summary: 'Hamilton,' which took home 11 awards in 2016, rewarded its team with nearly $700,000 in extra pay. A Broadway production that is nominated for multiple Tony Awards can often see a sizable bump at the box office. And if the show proves victorious, the payoff can be greater.

title: Father Is in Custody After Toddler's Death in Burning Car
summary: Police say a metal chain was looped around the handle of a rear-passenger door. The father of a 3-year-old Queens girl who died after being trapped in a burning car with a metal chain looped around the handle of a rear passenger door was in police custody Monday and expected to be criminally charged, police officials said.

title: Sysco Leans on Cost Cutting After Sales Miss Estimates
summary: Shares were up in late-afternoon trading on better-than-predicted adjusted profit. Sysco Corp. said cost cutting helped its results in the latest quarter after sales at the food distributor were softer than expected.

title: The Inspector-General Shortage
summary: Appointing more of them would instill much-needed public confidence in institutions.. title: Trump's Blunt Ambassador to Berlin
summary: Richard Grenell isn't apologizing, though he's ruffled even pro-American feathers.. Berlin

title: Jerry Nadler's Contempt
summary: The House Judiciary chairman is more interested in spectacle than information.. Poor Jerry Nadler.

title: Kamala Harris Lets Another Fish Get Away
summary: Her weird questions perplexed Barr but did him no damage.. The reviews are in, and Sen. Kamala Harris's performance during Attorney General William Barr's testimony last week was a hit! "Kamala Harris Guts Barr Like a Fish, Leaves Him Flopping on the Deck," Vanity Fair announced. The only problem with her made-for-TV performance is that Ms. Harris's questions were absurd-so vague or weird that they perplexed the attorney general.

title: 'The Beneficiary' Review: Questions of Inheritance
summary: A memoir of a Main Line Philadelphia family shaped by the whims of economic and social history and 'the strands of the double helix.'. Parents are tricky figures, intimately familiar and simultaneously mysterious; creators who are also, to some degree, strangers. The desire to figure them out-to excavate their secrets, their buried histories, the influences that shaped them long before they became our parents-is ancient and irresistible. In "solving" them, we hope to solve ourselves. For Janny Scott, solving her father-the Duke of Villanova, a figure who had always seemed "at some level unknowable"-meant uncovering a family history that stretched back to the 19th century.

title: Illinois Man Sentenced to 16 Years for Chicago Bomb Plot
summary: Judge factored in Adel Daoud's mental health in imposing sentence much lower than prosecutors requested. CHICAGO-A federal judge on Monday handed an Illinois man a 16-year prison sentence for attempting to kill hundreds of people by trying to detonate what he thought was a car bomb outside a crowded Chicago bar in 2012.

title: NYPD Bill Would Require Precinct Data on Major Solved Crimes
summary: Councilman Rory Lancman cites reports of low clearance rates for nondomestic homicides in parts of New York City. A New York City Council bill being introduced this week would require the New York Police Department to provide more-detailed information on how often it solves major crimes.

title: Treasury Department Rejects Democrats' Request for Trump Tax Returns
summary: Move is likely to send the dispute into federal court. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin rejected House Democrats' request for President Trump's tax returns, a move that was expected after he had contended for weeks that lawmakers were trying to expose details of the president's finances rather than conducting legitimate legislative oversight.

title: Why Trump Is Raising Tariffs on China
summary: The president's tough line will reduce friction later by giving Beijing an incentive to comply with a trade deal.. Are prospects for a U.S.-China trade deal fading? That was the conventional interpretation of President Trump's Sunday tweet, in which he said he'd raise tariffs from 10% to 25% on $200 billion of Chinese exports at the end of this week. Mr. Trump's announcement shocked China's leaders because they underestimated the strength of American hawks' influence, just as Americans once underestimated the influence of Chinese hawks. But the president's tough line now-heading into the final stretch of negotiations-will reduce friction later. China is less likely to cheat on any future agreement if it needs to comply to earn a reduction of these tariffs. China will cheat if the U.S. has no tariffs to enforce it.

title: Mind the Productivity Gap to Reduce Inequality
summary: It isn't only an American problem, but the U.S. has lessons to learn from other wealthy countries.. How are American workers doing? Neither the middle class nor the poor have fared well in recent decades-but don't blame tax cuts, a too-low minimum wage or the greed of the 1%. In rich countries around the world, the top half of the income distribution has been pulling away from the bottom half. Productivity growth among high-wage workers, driven by technological change, is the reason.

title: Judge Jails Hedge Fund Founder
summary: Platinum Partners founder Mark Nordlicht jailed for rest of trial after prosecutors said he tried to intimidate assistant U.S. attorney. A federal judge in Brooklyn jailed the founder of defunct hedge fund Platinum Partners after government lawyers said he accosted a prosecutor during a break in his trial.

title: Misplaced Coffee Cup on 'Game of Thrones' Brews Buzz for Starbucks
summary: Sunday's episode showed Daenerys Targaryen with what appeared to be one of the chain's cups within reach. Plenty of brands would like to find a way into an ad-free smash TV show like HBO's "Game of Thrones." On Sunday night, Starbucks Corp. seemed to have lucked its way there.

title: Rolls-Royce Looks to CTO to Reduce Carbon Footprint
summary: Tech chief spearheads effort to make jet-engine maker greener. summary: U.S.-China trade tensions raise economic uncertainty. The dollar rose against a number of emerging-market currencies Monday, as renewed trade tensions between the U.S. and China spooked some investors.

title: Turkey Cancels Istanbul Mayoral Election Won by Opposition
summary: Ruling AKP says balloting was marred by fraud and irregularities, but outraged mayor's party calls situation a matter of wanting to preserve control. ISTANBUL-Turkey's national election board canceled results of the Istanbul mayoral race that President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's ruling party lost five weeks ago and ordered a rerun, sparking outrage in opposition ranks and fueling investor concerns over heightened economic volatility.

title: Stocks Rebound From Steep Earlier Losses on U.S.-China Trade Worries
summary: Dow closes slightly lower after an earlier drop of more than 450 points, as investors shrugged off trade anxiety. Anxiety surrounding the U.S.-China trade spat swung U.S. stocks Monday, sending them down sharply in the morning before they pared most of their losses with an afternoon rally.

title: Gaza, Israel Reach Cease-Fire After Days of Deadly Clashes
summary: Calm descends after a weekend of rocket fire from Gaza and explosions on both sides of the border. TEL AVIV-Militant groups in Gaza said Monday they had reached a cease-fire with Israel after two days of the deadliest fighting since the 2014 war.

title: Share the Wealth
summary: A new program encourages regional museums to get their art out of storage and lend works to smaller institutions..

title: Put American Workers Ahead of Foreigners
summary: If there really is a "downward spiral" in skilled workers as the Economic Innovation Group finds, it's because of these visa programs. The abuse of the H-1B visa program is as old as the program itself.. Regarding Matthew J. Slaughter's "Immigrants for the Heartland" (op-ed, April 29): I disagree with importing more foreign workers. Our entire IT department at Siemens ICN was ordered by corporate management to train our replacements, who were Tata India employees on H-1B/L-1B visas. The well-educated American employees were given a small severance and a pink slip. Our extremely diverse department was replaced with an all-young, male, foreign workforce.

title: Arbitration or Not, Small Suits Are Doomed
summary: A good lawyer is going to charge you $500 or more per hour. If your case is less than $10,000, you'll lose money if you win, and the companies know that. Any claim under $50,000 probably isn't worth pursuing.. You keep promoting arbitration as a preferred method to a lawsuit ("Another Ninth Circuit Spanking," Review & Outlook, April 25). Your editorial suggests that arbitration is akin to small-claims court: You, a corporate representative and an arbitrator all work it out. It's not quite that simple. Without a lawyer, you don't stand a chance against a corporate lawyer who does this for a living.

title: 'Medicare for All' May Kill the Good Enough
summary: Before today's progressive utopians start crafting a Medicare for All Act of whatever reach, they need to address the imminent threat of actuarial doom in the current Medicare program.. Regarding Robert C. Pozen's "'Medicare for All' Isn't Medicare" (op-ed, May 2): Medicare isn't a typical insurer, it's more like a reinsurer, and one would expect that the administrative costs of a reinsurer to be lower. Further, you don't replace private administration with public employees and expect costs to go down, since public-labor costs are significantly higher. Anyone comparing the debacle of the government takeover of student loans or ObamaCare's promises and results should easily see how Medicare for All makes no sense.

title: A Right to Work Challenges Union-Forced Mediocrity
summary: Unfortunately, performance in the job had no effect on my pay. I could be the best teacher or the worst teacher and would still receive my salary based on the pay schedule, which was based on tenure.. Regarding your editorial "Banning Right-to-Work Laws" (April 29: As a former teacher in the right-to-work state of Iowa, I wasn't a member of the union, not because of dues, but because the union's beliefs and my beliefs differed significantly. As a then recent college graduate, I was locked into the pay schedule with no opportunity to improve my pay unless I got a master's degree. Unfortunately, performance in the job had no effect on my pay. I could be the best teacher or the worst teacher and would still receive my salary based on the pay schedule, which was based on tenure. I disagree with this philosophy.

title: Maybe NYU Should Change Name of 'President's' Award
summary: I am happy that the president of NYU has reaffirmed the university's support of its Jewish students.. Regarding New York University President Andrew Hamilton's letter "NYU Is Committed to Its Jewish Community" (April 30): I am happy that the president of NYU has reaffirmed the university's support of its Jewish students. But since he says neither he nor his staff participates in the selection of winners, maybe the first step would be to remove "President's" from the misnamed President's Service Awards.

title: Corinthian Capital Fined for Misusing Fund Assets
summary: Firm agreed to pay a $100,000 penalty in a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. title: Tech, Industrial Stocks Slide on Renewed Trade Fears
summary: Declines signal Trump's latest tariff threat is weakening confidence in markets. Shares of technology and industrial companies reliant on Chinese demand slid Monday, a sign President Trump's latest tariff threat is eroding the optimism that has supported markets so far this year.

title: Canada's Housing Will Return to Growth, Central Bank Governor Says
summary: Tougher mortgage rules are effective and improving quality of new loans, Stephen Poloz says. title: Mexico Stanches Flow of Stolen Fuel
summary: New government turns tide on thieves tapping pipelines and sapping state-oil company's revenues. title: Tyson Says Hog Disease Impact to Linger for Years

summary: Suspect considered the translator an uncle, had nearly 180 phone transactions with him, court filings say. title: What Beyond Meat Can Teach Big Food
summary: Vegetable-based burger company's shares look expensive, but investors shouldn't brush aside the appeal of its products. Beyond Meat 's shares may have soared beyond reason, but the blockbuster initial public offering still holds valuable lessons for the food industry.

title: Fed Flags Risky Business Debt as Vulnerability for Financial System
summary: In second financial stability report, officials warn of growth in leveraged loans and elevated asset prices. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve identified rising sales of risky corporate debt as a top vulnerability facing the U.S. financial system, according to a report released Monday.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Get Lift From Trade Tensions
summary: Ten-year yield drops below 2.5% after Trump threatens to raise tariffs on Chinese imports. summary: Oil prices fell hard earlier on worries Trump's China tweets might derail a possible trade deal. • Oil prices ended higher Monday on geopolitical worries after the U.S. said it was sending an aircraft carrier and a strike force to the Middle East as a warning to Iran. The rise in oil prices was a rebound from earlier in the session, when crude fell hard on worries that Twitter postings by President Trump might derail a possible U.S.-China trade deal.

title: House Panel to Vote on Holding Barr in Contempt
summary: Judiciary Committee move comes after Justice Department misses deadline for unredacted Mueller report. title: With South Africa at a Crossroads, President Seeks Middle Path in Vote

title: Stanley Collender Explained the U.S. Budget to Contractors and Even Federal Employees
summary: Quotable consultant worked on House and Senate committees, then found he was in hot demand for analysis. When Stanley Collender won an internship on the staff of the Senate Budget Committee in the 1970s, it must have sounded like a dull gig to a student who had never excelled at math. Starting in the 1980s, however, the fast-talking New York native discovered how lucrative it could be to explain the complexities of the U.S. budget to defense contractors and other beneficiaries of government spending.

summary: Weak manufacturing data and a stronger dollar have sent copper, aluminum and lead prices sliding but a U.S.-China trade deal could lend support. Prices for industrial metals are slumping, renewing investor concerns that pockets of weakness remain in the global economy.

summary: Fundraisers to gather at Trump International Hotel for pitch on president's 2020 contribution-'bundler' program. title: Men Who Love Streetwear-and Dress Their Dogs to Match
summary: Pet brands like Very Important Puppies and Pawmain are selling flashy hoodies and leashes for our four-legged friends. ACCORDING TO the American Pet Products Association, we spent over $72.5 billion on supplies for our furry friends in 2018. While much of that bought the sort of utilitarian gear you can find at Petco, high-end pet clothing has been a thriving market since at least the early aughts, when Paris Hilton paraded her chihuahua/prop Tinkerbell around in designer outfits. Today, that market has given rise to an attention-getting micro-genre: canine streetwear. Hoodies that accommodate pointy ears, sneaker-shaped chew toys and even designer turtlenecks echo the styles found in human hypebeasts' closets.

The sultan of Brunei said the tiny oil-rich kingdom won't enforce newly implemented Islamic laws that punish gay sex and adultery with death by stoning, after the country was hit by international condemnation and a boycott campaign.

title: A Little CBD to Take the Edge Off-For Your Pet?
summary: Products containing the hemp extract have garnered a flurry of interest among fans who take it for everything from sleep to stress reduction. Now, people are trying it on their pets.. Barbara Hightower has found a solution to her 9-year-old dog Moose's panic attacks: Treats made from cannabis.

title: Rivals Vie for Mastery Over America's Hottest Oil Field
summary: Bidding war for Anadarko Petroleum shows value of Permian Basin, the heart of U.S. fracking boom. Companies are clamoring for a bigger piece of the prolific oil field that has lifted U.S. crude production to records.

title: Homeowners Fault Government for Hurricane Harvey Damage
summary: Houston area residents allege the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers knew houses were at risk and now, under eminent domain law, owe them compensation. KATY, Texas-With lush parks, solid schools nearby and its proximity to Houston, the Cinco Ranch planned community seemed the perfect place for Elisio and Ana Soares to buy a house after moving to the U.S. from Brazil.

title: Growth Is Great, What Could Go Wrong? Trade.
summary: Investors have been ignoring a big contradiction in the current rally. Inflation is low, unemployment is low, fish are jumping, and the cotton is high. What could go wrong?

title: Moscow Plane Fire Kills at Least 41
summary: Aeroflot passenger aircraft catches fire after emergency landing; Vladimir Putin orders investigation. MOSCOW-A Russian passenger plane caught fire after an emergency landing at one of Moscow's main airports on Sunday, killing at least 41 people and triggering a criminal probe of the incident, according to Russian state media.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: XFL Strikes TV Deals With Fox and Disney
summary: Deals are expected to give visibility to Vince McMahon's reboot of NFL rival nearly 20 years after initial launch.

title: Making Monkeys Out of the Sohn Investing Gurus
summary: Randomly selected stocks beat the picks made by last year's Sohn Conference headliners. No animals were harmed in this financial experiment, but some human egos were bruised.

title: Want David Solomon's Take on Something? Buy a Goldman Share and Show Up
summary: Mindee Wasserman, a fixture at the annual shareholder meeting for years, helps liven an otherwise uneventful affair. When Goldman Sachs Group Inc. opened its annual meeting Thursday to Q&A, Mindee Wasserman beelined for the microphone.

title: As Diplomacy Shifts, U.S. Expands Military-Style Training
summary: Sites are added to aid governments in Africa, Southeast Asia as diplomacy faces potential cuts. DAKAR, Senegal-The U.S. State Department is opening new, military-style training facilities around the world, expanding plans to prop up local forces battling terrorism as the Trump administration seeks cutbacks in conventional diplomacy and development programs.

title: Sri Lanka Bombers Blew Up Motorcycles, Lost Fingers Honing Deadly Skills
summary: Authorities cite evidence that local planners followed terror group's designs from the internet to build bombs used in a series of suicide bombings that left more than 250 people dead. COLOMBO, Sri Lanka-The devastating Easter Sunday bombings in Sri Lanka were locally planned and executed, without direct guidance from the Islamic State militant group, investigators said.

title: U.S. Deploys Forces to Mideast to Deter Iran
summary: New intelligence suggests allied interests and American forces could be imperiled. WASHINGTON-The U.S. is deploying a carrier strike group and a number of bombers to the Middle East to serve as a deterrent to Iran based on new intelligence that suggests allied interests and American forces could be imperiled, multiple U.S. officials said.

title: What We've Learned About Target-Date Funds, 10 Years Later
summary: A decade after target-date funds were damaged during the financial crisis, they have re-emerged bigger than ever as retirement investments. But they still have vulnerabilities.. Back in 2008, many investors looking ahead to retirement in two years had a shock when "target-date funds" designed for them plummeted in value. Many had assumed those funds, targeted to a 2010 retirement, were safe from large moves that late in the game.

title: Your Fund Fees Might Still Vary More Than They Should-Especially on Index Funds
summary: Many investors feel trapped into paying high fees. Here's why, and what they can do. Marianne Swenson, a Boston-based labor lawyer, had done her research; she knew that the less she paid in fees for the mutual funds in her 401(k) portfolio, the more money she'd have to grow in her nest egg over the years. And she knew that there were plenty of S&P 500 index funds-a key ingredient in the portfolios of many fee-conscious investors-charging less than 0.10% a year.

title: U.S.-Stock Funds Rose 3.6% in April, Add to 2019 Gains
summary: During April, two risks that worried investors in 2018, fears about a possible government shutdown and a trade war with China, vanished. No one can be sure how long this will last. But the average U.S.-stock fund investor is enjoying every month's portfolio statement so far in 2019.

title: In Tough Times for Hedge Funds, These Are the Ones That Stand Out
summary: The hedge-fund industry has trailed the market for 10 straight years, but our review shows that many smaller funds are doing well. The hedge-fund industry continued its losing streak last year.

title: What Is Divergence in Markets?
summary: The word divergence gets used in at least two distinct areas of market analysis. When market analysts use the word "divergence," it often isn't clear what they mean. That's a problem because how it is used and in what context has implications for investors.

title: A Bond ETF Tries to Balance Risk
summary: The iShares Edge U.S. Fixed Income Balanced Risk fund has prospered in recent years with a strategy that aims to balance interest rate risk and credit risk. Investors must consider both interest-rate risk and credit risk to prosper in the fixed-income market.

title: Why the Good Times for Growth Stocks May Not Be Over
summary: Many investors believe it's time for value stocks to take the lead. Not so fast.. Growth stocks are on an uncommon roll as corporate profits chug on. But you might not want to bet on this long winning streak ending soon.

title: ETFs Hope to Connect With 5G Theme
summary: The FIVG trading symbol is already taken, yes, but many other funds are planning to play the 5G theme. Fund managers are dialing up their interest in 5G.

title: What to Know About 'Nontransparent' ETFs
summary: With this new category, managers don't have to disclose all the fund's investments every day. You'll be hearing more about "nontransparent" exchange-traded funds, now that the Securities and Exchange Commission is poised to approve a wave of them.

title: A New Way to Think About Momentum Investing
summary: It's easier to capitalize on momentum investing if you bet on the hottest factors (like large vs. small), rather than the best-performing actual stocks, a study suggests. Researchers recently uncovered an easier and more effective way of profiting from Wall Street's infamous momentum effect.

title: Occidental Raises Cash Portion of Anadarko Bid
summary: Company also reveals plan to sell assets as it seeks to outduel Chevron for Anadarko. Occidental Petroleum Corp. revised its offer for Anadarko Petroleum Corp. , increasing the cash portion of its bid and removing any requirement for a shareholder vote as the company seeks to best Chevron Corp. in a contest for prized assets in the heart of the U.S. oil boom.

title: Trump Issues China Tariff Threat
summary: President's warning to China takes Beijing by surprise. President Trump threatened to drastically ramp up U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports, a surprise twist that put an accord in doubt as Beijing considered pulling out of talks scheduled to begin this week.

title: The Cottage Industry for Artists Among the 'Game of Thrones' Faithful
summary: Resume Subscription. If emotional investment is key to making great art, then go ahead and put Robert Ball's latest piece in a museum. The London-based graphic artist wept during last week's "Game of Thrones" episode that inspired his illustration, and misted up again during the four-day process of creating it.
